summary:
After completing my graduate studies at the Vrije Universiteit van Amsterdam, I did a PhD on regional geology, which focussed on fore arc tectonics in Indonesia at the Netherlands Institute for Sea Research. This was followed by a post doc at the Geological Survey of Japan, where I studied back arc evolution along the eastern Japan Sea.

 A second post doc at the University of Liverpool dealt with clastic turbidite fan systems in the Karoo (South Africa). Finally, a third post doc was conducted at the University of Brunei, where I worked with a 3D seismic volume covering the continental slope. 

I firmly entered the oil industry after landing at Shell, where I worked for 6 years. Initially, I spent three years at Rijswijk (The Netherlands) where I became involved in New Venture Projects in Africa (Mozambique, Tunisia and Nigeria). This was followed by an assignment at Shell Brunei (BSP), where I worked on deep water projects (regional framework studies, prospect mapping, volumetrics and risking and ranking of toe thrust turbidite prospects). 

I subsequently moved to Petronas Brunei, where I had the opportunity to be involved in maturing and drilling related deep water prospects in the neighbouring exploration blocks. By doing so, I completed an exploration cycle and evolved from a turbidite geologist into a deep water explorationist. 

During my final two year job assignment with Genel Energy, I was engaged in frontier hydrocarbon evaluation projects, which addressed the regional geological history of Somaliland, Ethiopia as well as western Morocco. I was also involved in the evaluation of farm-in projects in Mongolia, Kenya, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Senegal and the Canary Islands.

My interests range from exposure and involvement with different cultures, religions, languages,  sport (hockey) and exotic asian kitchen flavours.
